result.markdown: --- title: "\U0001F578 Networks" subtitle: How things are connected author: "Arvind Venkatadri" date: 21/Nov/2022 date-modified: "2023-03-26" order: 100 abstract: "Networks and Connections and what happens over them" image: preview.jpg image-alt: image from rawpixel.com tags: - Nodes and Edges - Network Diagrams - Tree Diagrams - Arc Diagrams --- ## {{< fa folder-open >}} Slides and Tutorials | | Orange Tutorial | Networks in RÂ  | | |---------------|-----------------|---------------------------|---------------| ## {{< iconify noto-v1 package >}} Setting up R Packages ::: {.cell hash='networks_cache/html/setup_358cded0b6a06a48778790ae44358680'} ```{.r .cell-code} knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE) library(tidyverse) library(tidygraph) library(ggraph) library(graphlayouts) library(ggraph) library(graphlayouts) library(igraphdata) library(sand) ``` ::: ## {{< iconify openmoji japanese-symbol-for-beginner >}} Introduction Network graphs show relationships between entities: what sort they are, how strong they are, and even of they change over time. We will examine data structures pertaining both to the *entities* and the *relationships* between them and look at the data *object* that can combine these aspects together. Then we will see how these are plotted, what the *structure* of the plot looks like. There are also *metrics* that we can calculate for the network, based on its structure. We will of course examine geometric metaphors that can represent various classes of entities and their relationships. Network graphs can be rendered both as static and interactive and we will examine R packages that render both kinds of plots. There is a another kind of structure: one that combines *spatial* and *network* data in one. We will defer that for a future module ! {{< video https://youtu.be/DrhhdekP1ZQ >}} ## What kind Network graphs will we make?
